docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Two issues, reasonability and availability, are not commonly discussed when considering the disappointment of couples unable to conceive (front page, Dec. 14). Methods like in vitro fertilization are less effective in women over 40; in fact, pregnancy rates decline through the 30's.

headline.main: Childless Needn't Ride Fertility Roller Coaster ; Incoherent Coverage

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr David Kreiner and Dr Steven H Brenner calls for insurance mandate that includes realistic inclusion and exclusion criteria for in vitro fertilization (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to increase the state's cigarette tax by 40 cents a pack, making cigarettes more expensive in New Jersey than in any other state in the region. The proceeds, about $205 million a year, will help pay for hospital treatment for uninsured patients and for school construction. Both Republicans and Democrats offered unflinching support for the tax increase to 80 cents a pack, saying that they hoped it would curtail smoking, especially among teen-agers. The Senate voted 33-6 to adopt the proposal, while the General Assembly approved it 58-18. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to sign the bill into law, and the increase would take effect on Jan. 1.

headline.main: New Jersey Legislature Votes to Double State Cigarette Tax

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors' house calls are disappearing in the United States, in part because doctors have become dependent on modern medical technology, which they cannot carry in their black bags, researchers say. An analysis of Medicare claims in 1993 found that fewer than 1 percent of elderly patients received house calls. Most of those patients were very sick, the researchers said in a study being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: Doctors' Reliance on Technology Is Bringing House Calls to an End

docs.abstract: New study, based on Medicare claims, finds doctors' house calls are disappearing in United States, in part because doctors are dependent on modern medical technology they cannot carry with them; finds fewer than 1 percent of elderly patients got house calls in 1993; is published in New England Journal of Medicine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 40-cent increase in New Jersey's cigarette tax appeared all but inevitable today as a powerful legislative committee overwhelmingly approved the plan and lawmakers prepared for a general vote on Thursday. Although Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders have pushed for a cigarette tax increase several times in recent years, they have never found enough support for the proposal until now. The additional tax revenues would help cover the cost of hospital treatment for uninsured patients, replacing a financing system that expires on Dec. 31.

headline.main: Doubling of Cigarette Tax Grows Near in New Jersey

docs.abstract: Forty-cent increase in New Jersey's cigarette tax appears inevitable as powerful legislative committee overwhelmingly approves plan and lawmakers prepare for general vote on Dec 18; most of extra revenues--30 cents per pack of cigarettes--would help pay for hospital treatment for uninsured patients; remaining 10 cents per pack would go toward school construction projects; lawmakers predict tax revenues would provide $50 million a year for projects that are sorely needed in urban areas; law, if passed, will make New Jersey 10th state to pass cigarette tax increase in 1997 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers will have to comply for at least six months before they can obtain exemptions from a new law requiring broader insurance coverage of mental health services, Clinton Administration officials said today. The law, which takes effect on Jan. 1, is intended to curb discrimination in insurance. It says that group health plans may not impose lower limits on mental health benefits than on medical and surgical benefits for treating cancer, heart disease and other physical illnesses.

headline.main: Mental Care Has New Set Of Guidelines

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration officials say employers will have to comply for at least six months before they can obtain exemnptions from new law requiring broader insurance coverage of mental health services; law, which takes effect on January 1, 1998, is intended to curb discrimination in insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you were to have a heart attack tomorrow morning, you and your doctor would suddenly have to make a series of rapid-fire decisions about your medical care, including what hospital you should check into, what tests, medications and procedures you should receive, and what specialists you should see. But there is no single best way to care for a person with a heart attack. Dozens of approaches have been outlined in hundreds of textbook chapters and tens of thousands of research articles over the last few years. Old strategies grow obsolete and new ones appear daily. Would your doctor actually be able to sift through all that information to assemble the best, most up-to-date options for a person like you, and then organize your care accordingly?

headline.main: New Way of Doctoring: By the Book

docs.abstract: New technique of medical decision-making called 'evidence-based medicine' trains doctors to search medical journals and databases for tests and treatments that have helped large groups of patients; doctors then apply information to their own patients, under statistical assurance that what holds true for groups is likely to be valid for individuals; strategy is sweeping medicine in United States, Canada and Britain, widely hailed as crucial long-sought link between research and practice (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Because of their reliance on state subsidies and an adversarial stance toward physicians, New York hospitals find themselves in a crunch. Physicians, with their autonomous mentality and lack of business acumen, find themselves drifting. Can the two get together and control their financial destiny? A Dec. 13 news article, ''Hospitals and Unions Propose Takeover of Empire Blue Cross,'' raises this possibility.

headline.main: Overworked Doctors Must Respect Their Limits; Now Work Together

docs.abstract: Dr Sunil S Jhangiani letter comments on December 13 article on proposal by New York City hospitals and health workers union for takeover of Blue Cross and Blue Shield (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders tentatively agreed today to raise New Jersey's cigarette tax by at least 25 cents to help cover the cost of hospital treatment for uninsured patients, the Governor's top aide said. Additional money would come from the state's unemployment fund and the general budget, the aide said. Michael P. Torpey, the Governor's chief of staff, said that lawmakers would probably introduce a bill on Tuesday that would likely provide $315 million annually over five years to help hospitals cover the cost of treating tens of thousands of uninsured people. The plan would also provide $101.5 million a year for the state's Hospital Relief Fund, which helps urban hospitals treat hundreds of patients with AIDS and tuberculosis. The program would expire after five years.

headline.main: Tax on Cigarettes May Rise To Help Pay for Health Care
